comments: We have different criteria for adults burns (any) and kids burns (paed matrix score of 8 or less as far as I recall). So that particular question is not phrased properly. You asking for both adults and kids IN the same question, not anticipating that different hospitals may have different criteria for adults or kids. So Answer is very misleading for that particular question

hospital.statement: My hospital accepts patients with any burn size or complexity
theatre.type: My hospital has an operating theatre shared between burns and other surgical specialties e.g. vascular surgery, orthopaedic surgery
comments: Thank you for running this study, the results will be very interesting. It's a very well written survey, and easy to fill out. Note that oropharyngeal temp probes if advanced a little further generally go oesophageal; I've not seen a tracheal temp probe sited on purpose and temp readings exposed to ventilator gas flows tend to wildly underread because they are cooled by the gases, so you might want to change that tab to 'oropharyngeal or oesophageal' because that is more clinically realistic . In general, although I have listed all the options available to us in our unit for warming and cooling, I prefer to avoid using overhead radiant heaters with children where possible, due to concerns about drying out the burn. In addition to the listed measures, in small babies particularly, we use Transwarmers under patients to warm them and they can work very well. I try not to directly vasoconstrict a burn with topical cooling measures once normal first aid has been carried out. My thresholds for temperature management are probably different in the acute phase of a burn (when we might go to theatre to manage the temperature at almost any temp, even if we don't start  surgery straight away) compared with a scheduled visit later. See also my email to you, I'm very happy to discuss some of these aspects in detail if it is of interest,

comments: We take all sizes of burns for adults. We have a threshold of 30% for partial thickness and 20% deep demal/FT in children .  The figures and data given here are to the best of my knowledge

theatre.type: My hospital has an operating theatre shared between burns and general plastic surgery
min.temp.delay.surg: We do not have a set minimum patient body temperature before starting burn surgery
max.temp.delay.surg: We do not have a set maximum patient body temperature before starting burn surgery
preferred.min.temp.surg: We do not have a set minimum patient body temperature during burn surgery
set.max.temp.surg: We do not have a set maximum patient body temperature during burn surgery
comments: I am sorry I wasn't able to recall the admission numbers  - it would take further research to locate this data which I recognize is important for your results but I have not had the time to do so, if you need these particular details I can try to locate them for you.   We are a regional burn unit that can accept any TBSA but typically over 30% would be transferred to our national centre, this is not always possible due to bed capacity and hence they may stay with us.  I am not aware of any protocols in our hospital about temperature pre/post surgery but we strive for a normal body temp and respond if trending down. I would be interested to see if there are protocols in use in other centres that we could consider trial of in Christchurch.
